We have received files of the "Bl.t.9a Pack
ct'' Of the 10th and 9Th February.


The fact of the defcat of the Brazilian squad
ron on the Uruguay, by Admiral Brown, is fully
coroborated Seven vessels were captured on
the 9th and 10th February, and hopes were en-
tertained that the remainder would very soon
fall into the hands of the Patriots.


Rumours were current that 500 ncg"3es had
passed from the Brazilians TO the Republican
Army, and that leserters are continually joining
the army on its march. Among these are sever
II who had formerly abandoned their regiments
and gone over to the Braziiians but have ayaed
themselves Of procl nation offering them tall
pardon on returning to their duty


Several carts laden with provisions, intended
for the Brazilians, had been seized near Monte
ydeo, by the besicging troops. Circumstances
connected with the seizure, had transpired,
which arc said seriously involve the hnnour of
one of the superior officers Of the Republican
army


The news Of Browns victory over the Brazil
ian feet was cause of great rejoicing IN the CT
ty. For some time previous to the victory, the
p,l. lie were almost entirely ignorant oithe move
ments Of the squadron, as, by order Of the Admi-
raj, the publication of the correspondence had
been prohibited, to prevent the Brazilians &C
quiring any information Of his designs through
the channel of public papers For this reason,
the effect produced by the arrival Of the intell-
rcnce of the defeat and capture OF the Brazilian
division, was so much more powerful and gener-
al. II operated like electricity on the feelings
and energies of the whole population,--the
sympathy of enthusiasm seemed to act like wlia-
fire among tile most combustible materials Inc
day of the 10th had scarcely closed, before nni-
yersal demonstrations Of joy began to he display
ed bv bonfrcs, fireworks, and bands OF music
narading the streets, accompanied by immense
crowds of people expressing their pleasure N
loud and repeated Tira's to the heroes OF the
National Squadron and army, which, by happy
coincidence of circumstance. had about the sans
time gained several advantages over the Brazil
inn land forces, and the arrival of the Bulletin OF
the same evening with the account OF Brown
victory made it seem as if the guardian genus
the Republic had resolved on tiilng up TIT
measure of popular rejoicings. IN Ihe course

Mr.. Strickland, principal engineer. and
Judge Geddes. assistant engineer OF the
State Canal of Pennsylvania, have resigned
their appointment; and it is thought others
will follow their example.


The pew holders of St. Mary's Church,
in Philadelphia have had meeting. in con
sequence OF the dismissal of their Minister
the Rev. Mr.. Harold, by the Roman Catho.
lie Bishop CanweIl--they have protested
against the proceeding, and appointed a
Committee to appeal to higher power lot
redress. i.


A steam engine is at work deepening the
harbour at Delaware CITY.


The Boston Courier mentions two more
instances of the cure of persons who were
complete sots, by the use of DIR. Chambers
medicine. Neither of these men have tast
ed any spurious liquors since January.
The amount of manufactures in Cihcin
natl, in the year 1896, exceeded seveutee'
hundred thousand dollars.

DIED, at Cow Island Mosquito shore, Central
America on the 4th day Of April, 62i, Mr. WM.
M,CORKIE, late second mate ofthe brig MARY,
of philadelphia, and native of Wilmington, Del


The deceased bid fair to become an ornament
IN society, and an honour 10 his profession. In
his manners he was extremely prepossessin.s--
sincerity and honesty were stamped on his coan-
tenance, and his afability and general dcport-
~, Mt. endeared him to all who knew him. As q
son he was obedient-as a brother affection ate,
and as friend sincere in his attachments.


The Mary was from Carthagcna. bound
to New York, and was wrecked FEBRUARY
2ist. on the New Boar Shoal. The Captain
mate. an;. crew, after being three days II
the long boat, reached the Mosquito shore
and after residence Of nearly two months
among the Indians, Tin which time Mi
M'Corkle died of fever, and two CT tue cfe'
were murdered by the natives } the remain
der were taken off by Colombian schooner
and carried To- s. !ago.

No. IS, CAesnut Street, PHILADELPHIA,
OFFER for sale some superior Seed of the
~ MANGEL WURTZELL, or CATTLE
BEET-also, of the RUTA BAGA, or SWED-
ISL TURNIP.


The cultivation of these Crops is every season
becoming more enlarged, as their excellence as
food for stock becomes more generally known :
particularly the former, which is extremely nutris
tious, and the produce very great, ,--sirteen hun
dred bushels TO the acre, having been reared in the
neighbonrhood Of Philadelphia, with no more la
bonr, than good farmers bestow on Indian Corn.
For particulars as to the mode of cultivation, &c.
see Memoirs of the Pennsylvania Agricultural
Society.

T.. LETTELL,

On seeing him smile.
Smile on, sweet child! thy little heart,
Is far too young to know of care;
No earthly i'll can yet impart
Its bane, to mingle sadness there.
And oh! if might breathe for thee
A prayer to him who placed thee here
'Twere this-that thou should'st ever be
A stranger to affiiction's tear.
Iwould not ask for glittering aueahh,
Nor would wish for worldly famei
The one oft proves the bane of health,
The other, but an empty name.
would not wish to see thee shine,
And have the painful truth to know,
That Virtue, at .ambit,on's shrine,
Had paid for thy unmeaning show.
For oft on virtues injured wreck,
Ambitions ruthless fame is built;
And tho aueaHh may the body deck,
1t often lures the soul to guilt.
No, baby, no!-far from me


Shall ever be a prayer like this;-
Sweet boy! think too much of thee,
To ask for perishabie bliss.
For well know this fading earth,


With all its train Of honors fair;
Nor cen its gayest scenes of mirth,
Can check the canker-worm of care.
The brightest flowers that ever bloom'd,
Ofsweetest scent-of fairest form,--
Have more or less, dear child, been doom'd
To wither by some blighting storm.
Then be it mine to ask for thee


boon which earth can ne'er impart;
A rirtious mind,-a conscience free,-
pous and spotiess heart.

The Liverpool docks were so crowded on the
10Th March, that there was no room for about SO
s4ll of vessels, which had been obliged TO remain
asanchor several days in the river. No vessel
sailed for the United States between the 10th
ana 18th of March, except the William Thomp-
son, which vessel was towed out Of port by steam
boats.

Day before yesterday, <Ineslay) whilst
some boys we're playing in q boat at the whaii,
one ofthem, a son Of Mr.. Peter O'Daniel ac
cidentally fell into the dock and was drown
ed. Assistance was Immediately called, aud


after he had remained under water about
three or four Minutes, he was fshed up with
boat-hook; but all attempts to resuscitate
him failed, and he was presented 70 his heart
broken parents lfcless corpse. This mel
ancholy event should be a warning to all Loys
who are fond Of playing about theswharves


There are many who seek every leisure NO
ment to amuse themselves BY getting into
small boats and pushing about the docks


and thus we sec, at moment when least eN'
pected, death is the price OF their pleasure

The brig Virginia, at Baltimore, brings
late and interesting intelligence from Rio
Janeiro and the La Plata The editors of
the Baltimore American announce the re-
ceipt of advices from the former place to
the 18th March; by which We are informed
Of the capture of the American brig Spark,
which was taken possession of at the insti-
CATION Of the Minister of Marines at Rio, and
the crew mal-treated and imprisoned-
This outrage upon the rights and liberties Of
American citizens. trading to free port, is


looked upon as a source of some future trou
bic to his imperial highness Don Pedro.


The Charge d 'Aflaires, Mr.. Racquet, has, in
consequence Of a refuss! on the part of the


authorities to give proper satisfaction, &C
companed with insulting language, demand


ed his passports, and intends returning
+ home i'll the first vessel.

Thursday, May II, 1927.

An application has been made in England
to obtain a patent for an invention TO clear
London from the dense cloud Of smoke IN
which it is generallv involved. The plan Is
to convey the exhalAtioas in snhterraneous
fues to distance from the city.

The drinking of spurious liquors has been pro
hbitedin IN one Of tile islands OF o@yhee, under
tie penalty ofive hogs: the chiefs, who are INC
law makers, no doubt, having discovered that
the excessive use Of strong drink assimilated men
to hogs and they conceived Of SO appropriate
penalty,

TvHE Subscriber begs leave to offer himselfto
i the Democratic Citizens Of Newcastle Coun-
ty for the office of SHERIFF, to be supplied in
october next; assuring them that in case he
should be the object their choice, his best ex-
ertions shall be employed to execute the duties
of the Office with fidelity; and pledging himself
to abide by the decision of the County Meeting,
to be held at the Red Lion, for the nomination Of
the County Ticket.


ALEXANDER PORTER.

The Maidstone Gazette gives the following as
the copy of letter written and actually sent by
an uiTeciionatc wife to her husband, who having
been capitally convicted, was sent on board the
Gonynede, hulk, at Woowich. The woman is
at present resident at a town III the eastern part
O: this county. For obvious reasons We omit
names, but give the ramaiuder ierbdtim as il was
written.


Dear Husband, Feb. Cd, 1897,


| take this opportunity Of addressing these
few lines to you, hoping to find you in good
health as it leaves inc at present thank God Tor
!t-Ocar husband am gong to change my line
Of life and hope it will be for the better must
tell you am going to be married and hope you
have no objection for you know you have not
behaved to Inc as a husband ought to have done
both you and your family have used me very i'll
But every one knows that never gave you any
reason to i'll treet me.


have been to the overcears 10 ask they're ad-
Hice what am to do and they told me | had bet
Ter get another husband as did not expect you
would ever come home again You need not fret
about it nor make yourself in the least alarmed
itwhat I say for can assure you it is true.


The Overscars of the Parish is goingto give
The man ten pounds to take me out of the Parish
have invited your Brother Robert to the We'd
end and wish you was at home to make one
among us--I shall tell you the mans name is
William ----


You need not forget me for all that If you
should ever come where am hope yon will
call and see ME So conclude and still relnuil
your affectionatc wife
William - CATHERINE ----.--
Gadmced Ship
Woolegc

two, three, or four pounds each, under pen.

bread for the use of the poor.

Tha winter has been extremely severe
and tempestuous in Prussia. In some parts
Of the province of Glatz, the snow has been
SO deep that the inhabitants OF some OF the
villages have been Obliged to form tunnels
uader it. in order to get to and from their
dwellings.

person in Plymouth, Mass. came near
being burnt to death on the night OF the s5th
ult from the bad practice of reading IN bed.
He was reused from his sleep by the snap
ping Of burning feathers under his head; he
was enabled to extinguish it by a presence
Of mind which every one does not possess.

Farmers are turning their attention to the
culture Of hops. The general use of beer
has created demand for hops and barley
1t is curious fact, that there was petition
before the English Parliament in 1923, tor
the cxtermination of hops, from the country,
fer being wicked weeds"

To the polite attention of MIR. Elisha IN.
Sink, who came passenger III the Virginia.
the Editors are indebted for the following
full report Of the state Of affairs in the LA
Plata. Mr.. S. left the city OF Rusnos ayres
on the 9Th February, and Monte,ideo on the
18th of the same month"; He states that on
the 8th Admiral Brown had an engagement
with the BRAZILIAN squadron IN the Curu-
quay. in which he captured six sail and SUNK
two The rest, about eleven in number, es-
capcd up the river Browns loss was one
small vessel. 1t is certain, however, that
the Brazilian vessels cannot long hold out. as
they have but little to cat, and can derive
no supplies from the shores which are occu-
ped by the Patriot soldicry. All hope OF
supply from the main squadron is cut OFT, as
Brown has strongly fortified the island OF
Martin Garcia, and has placed his vessels
across the channel of the river. a few days
previous he had captured a small brazilian
schooner containing gunpowder and seven
hundred Patagonias. The large vessels OF
the Buenos Ayrcan navy, consisting OF the
"Twenty fifth of May" the barque Con
srcsso, the brig Republicana. and brig In
depeneiencia, we're lying in the inner ROADS
Of Buenos Ayres, with top-masts housed and
soldiers ON board. The blockading squad
ron was lying in the outer roads, consisting
Of the frigate Inperatrice. corvette Liberal
and brig "29th of August

cd nearly half the square opposite the lheatfe'

fore the flames were finally eAtinguished-

Penrant records an ill.natured provcrb APP
plicablc to the Carse of Gowric, that sthey want
water in the summer, fire in the winter, and the
grace of God all the year round" We have,
moreover, derived from an original source the
following anacdote Illustrative of this SUBJECT
A landed gentleman of the Carse, used to com
plain very much Of the awkwardness and stupid
itv Of all the men whomhe employed, declaring,
that if he were only furnished with good clay,
he believed lie could make better men himself.
This ridiculous TRADE got wind among the peas
antrv, and excited their no small indignation. =
One Of their class soon afterwards found an OPP
portuni:y of revenging himself and neighbours
upon the author, by cut with his own weapon.
II so happened that the laird was SO unfortunate
one day as to fall into a quagmire, the material
of which was of such nature as to hold INN tass,
and put cxtrication entirely out Of his own pow
er. In his dilemma, observing a peasant aap
preaching, he called out to him, and desired h,'
assistance, in order that he might get hinsei
relieved from his unpleasant confinement. The
rustic, recognizing him Immediately, paid no ut
tention to his cntrcaties, but passed carelessly
by; only giving him one knowing look, and say


ng-si see ye're making your men, laird III ne
disturb ye


TGhambers Popular Rhymes Of Scotland.

full articles.headline: FROM DUENos AYRrs
full articles.article:
We have received files of the "Bl.t.9a Pack
ct'' Of the 10th and 9Th February.


The fact of the defcat of the Brazilian squad
ron on the Uruguay, by Admiral Brown, is fully
coroborated Seven vessels were captured on
the 9th and 10th February, and hopes were en-
tertained that the remainder would very soon
fall into the hands of the Patriots.


Rumours were current that 500 ncg"3es had
passed from the Brazilians TO the Republican
Army, and that leserters are continually joining
the army on its march. Among these are sever
II who had formerly abandoned their regiments
and gone over to the Braziiians but have ayaed
themselves Of procl nation offering them tall
pardon on returning to their duty


Several carts laden with provisions, intended
for the Brazilians, had been seized near Monte
ydeo, by the besicging troops. Circumstances
connected with the seizure, had transpired,
which arc said seriously involve the hnnour of
one of the superior officers Of the Republican
army


The news Of Browns victory over the Brazil
ian feet was cause of great rejoicing IN the CT
ty. For some time previous to the victory, the
p,l. lie were almost entirely ignorant oithe move
ments Of the squadron, as, by order Of the Admi-
raj, the publication of the correspondence had
been prohibited, to prevent the Brazilians &C
quiring any information Of his designs through
the channel of public papers For this reason,
the effect produced by the arrival Of the intell-
rcnce of the defeat and capture OF the Brazilian
division, was so much more powerful and gener-
al. II operated like electricity on the feelings
and energies of the whole population,--the
sympathy of enthusiasm seemed to act like wlia-
fire among tile most combustible materials Inc
day of the 10th had scarcely closed, before nni-
yersal demonstrations Of joy began to he display
ed bv bonfrcs, fireworks, and bands OF music
narading the streets, accompanied by immense
crowds of people expressing their pleasure N
loud and repeated Tira's to the heroes OF the
National Squadron and army, which, by happy
coincidence of circumstance. had about the sans
time gained several advantages over the Brazil
inn land forces, and the arrival of the Bulletin OF
the same evening with the account OF Brown
victory made it seem as if the guardian genus
the Republic had resolved on tiilng up TIT
measure of popular rejoicings. IN Ihe course

Mr.. Strickland, principal engineer. and
Judge Geddes. assistant engineer OF the
State Canal of Pennsylvania, have resigned
their appointment; and it is thought others
will follow their example.

in Philadelphia have had meeting. in con
sequence OF the dismissal of their Minister
the Rev. Mr.. Harold, by the Roman Catho.
lie Bishop CanweIl--they have protested
against the proceeding, and appointed a
Committee to appeal to higher power lot
redress. i.


A steam engine is at work deepening the
harbour at Delaware CITY.


The Boston Courier mentions two more
instances of the cure of persons who were
complete sots, by the use of DIR. Chambers
medicine. Neither of these men have tast
ed any spurious liquors since January.

natl, in the year 1896, exceeded seveutee'

full articles.headline: MARRIED,
full articles.article:
On Monday, 9TH inst, at Lancaster, "a oy Ha-
thaniel Lightner, Mayor, Mr.. MARSHALL Pull
Lips to Miss MARY MATILDA GRxGG, both OF Wll.
mington, Del


asvez.szz1ssnu<',s.


DIED, at Cow Island Mosquito shore, Central
America on the 4th day Of April, 62i, Mr. WM.
M,CORKIE, late second mate ofthe brig MARY,
of philadelphia, and native of Wilmington, Del


The deceased bid fair to become an ornament
IN society, and an honour 10 his profession. In
his manners he was extremely prepossessin.s--
sincerity and honesty were stamped on his coan-
tenance, and his afability and general dcport-
~, Mt. endeared him to all who knew him. As q
son he was obedient-as a brother affection ate,
and as friend sincere in his attachments.


The Mary was from Carthagcna. bound
to New York, and was wrecked FEBRUARY
2ist. on the New Boar Shoal. The Captain
mate. an;. crew, after being three days II
the long boat, reached the Mosquito shore
and after residence Of nearly two months
among the Indians, Tin which time Mi
M'Corkle died of fever, and two CT tue cfe'
were murdered by the natives } the remain
der were taken off by Colombian schooner
and carried To- s. !ago.

full articles.headline:
TO AGRzCULTURIsTs.
q. s. 6. LANDRETH,
full articles.article:
No. IS, CAesnut Street, PHILADELPHIA,
OFFER for sale some superior Seed of the
~ MANGEL WURTZELL, or CATTLE
BEET-also, of the RUTA BAGA, or SWED-
ISL TURNIP.


The cultivation of these Crops is every season
becoming more enlarged, as their excellence as
food for stock becomes more generally known :
particularly the former, which is extremely nutris
tious, and the produce very great, ,--sirteen hun
dred bushels TO the acre, having been reared in the
neighbonrhood Of Philadelphia, with no more la
bonr, than good farmers bestow on Indian Corn.
For particulars as to the mode of cultivation, &c.
see Memoirs of the Pennsylvania Agricultural
Society.


1rRcfercncc may be had to c. & G. REY
NOIDS, No 60, Market-st, Wilmington; who
will receive and forward all orders which may be
left in their care.

full articles.headline:
For the TVilnsingtoalan.
TO MY INFANT NEPHEW,
full articles.article:
On seeing him smile.
Smile on, sweet child! thy little heart,
Is far too young to know of care;
No earthly i'll can yet impart
Its bane, to mingle sadness there.
And oh! if might breathe for thee
A prayer to him who placed thee here
'Twere this-that thou should'st ever be
A stranger to affiiction's tear.
Iwould not ask for glittering aueahh,
Nor would wish for worldly famei
The one oft proves the bane of health,
The other, but an empty name.
would not wish to see thee shine,
And have the painful truth to know,
That Virtue, at .ambit,on's shrine,
Had paid for thy unmeaning show.
For oft on virtues injured wreck,
Ambitions ruthless fame is built;
And tho aueaHh may the body deck,
1t often lures the soul to guilt.
No, baby, no!-far from me


Shall ever be a prayer like this;-
Sweet boy! think too much of thee,
To ask for perishabie bliss.
For well know this fading earth,


With all its train Of honors fair;
Nor cen its gayest scenes of mirth,
Can check the canker-worm of care.
The brightest flowers that ever bloom'd,
Ofsweetest scent-of fairest form,--
Have more or less, dear child, been doom'd
To wither by some blighting storm.
Then be it mine to ask for thee


boon which earth can ne'er impart;
A rirtious mind,-a conscience free,-
pous and spotiess heart.


BRANDYWINE MINSTREL.

The Liverpool docks were so crowded on the
10Th March, that there was no room for about SO
s4ll of vessels, which had been obliged TO remain
asanchor several days in the river. No vessel
sailed for the United States between the 10th
ana 18th of March, except the William Thomp-
son, which vessel was towed out Of port by steam
boats.

Day before yesterday, <Ineslay) whilst
some boys we're playing in q boat at the whaii,
one ofthem, a son Of Mr.. Peter O'Daniel ac
cidentally fell into the dock and was drown
ed. Assistance was Immediately called, aud


after he had remained under water about
three or four Minutes, he was fshed up with
boat-hook; but all attempts to resuscitate
him failed, and he was presented 70 his heart
broken parents lfcless corpse. This mel
ancholy event should be a warning to all Loys
who are fond Of playing about theswharves


There are many who seek every leisure NO
ment to amuse themselves BY getting into
small boats and pushing about the docks


and thus we sec, at moment when least eN'
pected, death is the price OF their pleasure

The brig Virginia, at Baltimore, brings
late and interesting intelligence from Rio
Janeiro and the La Plata The editors of
the Baltimore American announce the re-
ceipt of advices from the former place to
the 18th March; by which We are informed
Of the capture of the American brig Spark,
which was taken possession of at the insti-
CATION Of the Minister of Marines at Rio, and
the crew mal-treated and imprisoned-
This outrage upon the rights and liberties Of
American citizens. trading to free port, is


looked upon as a source of some future trou
bic to his imperial highness Don Pedro.


The Charge d 'Aflaires, Mr.. Racquet, has, in
consequence Of a refuss! on the part of the


authorities to give proper satisfaction, &C
companed with insulting language, demand


ed his passports, and intends returning
+ home i'll the first vessel.

she was pursued. captured and brough


back, under the plea Or suspicion that sh
was about to be converted into Bueno

and the crew experienced very harsh treat

Professor Carter, senior Editor cf the N
York Statesman, has returned home in the
packet ship Pacific, from Liverpool.

An application has been made in England
to obtain a patent for an invention TO clear
London from the dense cloud Of smoke IN
which it is generallv involved. The plan Is
to convey the exhalAtioas in snhterraneous
fues to distance from the city.

to hogs and they conceived Of SO appropriate
penalty,

SHER1FFALTY.
full articles.article:
TvHE Subscriber begs leave to offer himselfto
i the Democratic Citizens Of Newcastle Coun-
ty for the office of SHERIFF, to be supplied in
october next; assuring them that in case he
should be the object their choice, his best ex-
ertions shall be employed to execute the duties
of the Office with fidelity; and pledging himself
to abide by the decision of the County Meeting,
to be held at the Red Lion, for the nomination Of
the County Ticket.


ALEXANDER PORTER.
NAV II, 1927, 35-tf

The Maidstone Gazette gives the following as
the copy of letter written and actually sent by
an uiTeciionatc wife to her husband, who having
been capitally convicted, was sent on board the
Gonynede, hulk, at Woowich. The woman is
at present resident at a town III the eastern part
O: this county. For obvious reasons We omit
names, but give the ramaiuder ierbdtim as il was
written.


Dear Husband, Feb. Cd, 1897,


| take this opportunity Of addressing these
few lines to you, hoping to find you in good
health as it leaves inc at present thank God Tor
!t-Ocar husband am gong to change my line
Of life and hope it will be for the better must
tell you am going to be married and hope you
have no objection for you know you have not
behaved to Inc as a husband ought to have done
both you and your family have used me very i'll
But every one knows that never gave you any
reason to i'll treet me.


have been to the overcears 10 ask they're ad-
Hice what am to do and they told me | had bet
Ter get another husband as did not expect you
would ever come home again You need not fret
about it nor make yourself in the least alarmed
itwhat I say for can assure you it is true.


The Overscars of the Parish is goingto give
The man ten pounds to take me out of the Parish
have invited your Brother Robert to the We'd
end and wish you was at home to make one
among us--I shall tell you the mans name is
William ----


You need not forget me for all that If you
should ever come where am hope yon will
call and see ME So conclude and still relnuil
your affectionatc wife
William - CATHERINE ----.--
Gadmced Ship
Woolegc

two, three, or four pounds each, under pen.
atty Of ten dollars, and forfeiture OF the
bread for the use of the poor.

Tha winter has been extremely severe
and tempestuous in Prussia. In some parts
Of the province of Glatz, the snow has been
SO deep that the inhabitants OF some OF the
villages have been Obliged to form tunnels
uader it. in order to get to and from their
dwellings.

person in Plymouth, Mass. came near
being burnt to death on the night OF the s5th
ult from the bad practice of reading IN bed.
He was reused from his sleep by the snap
ping Of burning feathers under his head; he
was enabled to extinguish it by a presence
Of mind which every one does not possess.

Farmers are turning their attention to the
